page.title: 11Local History
page.content: By 1953, Sanquhar had expanded to include two council-built housing schemes, the streets being named after famous Covenanters and local families of note. One street, built in 1947, to house 28 mining families from Larkhall in Lanarkshire, was referred to as "Larkie Town". Three garages now coped with the needs of motorised transport, and electricity had replaced gas as the main source of power. The farms had become more mechanised, with horses being replaced by tractors and farmers were now able to attend markets outwith the immediate area. A few families now owned a television and a travelling cinema visited the town each Saturday (entrance fee being 5 jam jars).A large extension had been made to the school and a now defunct weekly newspaper, "The Nithsdale Observer", was published in the town.
